value:
/* REPLICATION FILES for the article:
Spillovers from High-Skill Consumption to Low-Skill Labor Markets 
Francesca Mazzolari and Giuseppe Ragusa
REStat, March 2013, 95(1), 74-86
* 
do file: 02_cex.do
*/
* This do file generates relevant variables for the analysis run on a sample drawn from the 2004 CEX Diary Survey
* The working sample is stored in the file diary04/cex_diary04.dta (generated by the do file 01_cex.do)
* The do file also contains the commands needed to replicate Table 1 and Figure 1 in the paper, as well as Table A1 and Figure A1 in the online appendix
* set path for WORKING DIRECTORY
*A. Generate variables and Descriptives
*WEIGHTS
*The CUs (consumer units) in the Diary survey microdata files represent the U.S. population
*In the original CEX files, the weighting variable "finlwt21" has been adjusted such that the sum of all CU weights for one month approximates one third of the U.S. population
*consequently, the weights for 3 months (one quarter) of data approximate the total U.S. population
*The file diary04/cex_diary04.dta is obtained by pooling 4 quarters of data
*As a result, the weights for 4 quarters of data approximate 4 TIMES the total U.S. population
*Expenditures are originally weekly amounts, so to get yearly expenditures from a dataset that pools the 4 quarters we should sum the (weekly)expenditure*weights*4 and then divide by 4!
*we have transformed them in monthly amounts and collapsed the (up to) two weekly observations for each CU (that is, for each separate "newid") into one observation (one "cuid")
*To get yearly expenditures from a dataset that pools the 4 quarters we should sum the (monthly)expenditure*weights and then divide by 4 and multiply by 2 (because 2 newid = 1 cuid)!
*so, we divide the weight by two in order to obtain yearly expenditures in weighted tabulations.
*ALSO, "finlwt21" is technically a FREQUENCY WEIGHT (it tells how many observations each entry represents); Stata would expect it to contain positive integers, while it has decimals
*round "finlwt21" at the closest integer to be able to run weighted estimates
*FAMILY TYPE
*Working status of woman in husband and wife (HW) families
*HEAD OF THE FAMILY
*The family head is conventionally fixed to be the male in all husband/wife (HW) families
*For comparison (see Table A1), we also set it equal to the woman (head_fem)
***Education***
*Generate 5 educational groups: for reference person and spouse
***Log hourly wages***
*Hourly wages of the reference person and the spouse defined using the following variables from the member file:
* wage_ref_fromM wks_wrkd_ref_fromM hrsperwk_ref_fromM
* wage_sp_fromM wks_wrkd_sp_fromM hrsperwk_sp_fromM
*of the reference person
*recode hourly wages in the bottom and top 1 percent of the distribution with the p1 and p99 values
*save the first and the 99th percentiles of hrwage from previous "summarize, det" command
*of the spouse
*recode hourly wages in the bottom and top 1 percent of distribution at the p1 and p99 values
*save the the first and 99th percentiles of hrwage from previous "summarize, det" command
*of the head (that is, conventionally the male in HW families) and the wife
*logarithmic transformation
* SAMPLE RESTRICTIONS
*** NT_home: expenditure items that are likely to refer to services/goods that are substitutes for home production *****
*B. GRAPHS of NT expenditure share (NT expenditure / total expenditure) for different educational levels / family types
*FIGURE 1
* Bar graph of the budget share in home services, by education of the head (set to be the male in all HW families) and by family type
*FIGURE A1
*in the case of husband & working wife families, use the education of the spouse instead of the education of the head
* FIGURE A2
* Bar graph of composition of expenditures in non-traded services that subsitute for home production, by education of the head
*C. RELATIONSHIP between NT expenditure share (NT expenditure / total expenditure) and log hourly wages
* Distribution of family types on regression sample
* Table 1: Correlation between household budget share of home production substitutes and household members' hourly wages; 2004
*each regression corresponds to a column of the table
*Column 1 - All families (Hourly wages of the reference person; any type of family)
*Column 2 - Husband/Wife families - Woman does NOT work
* Column 3 - Husband/Wife families - Woman works
* Column 4 - Husband/Wife families - Woman works - include both head's and wife's wage
*Other families
